title: 114_hr4376
content:
The "Pay Stub Disclosure Act" is the short title of the Act. The Act includes findings related to pay stub disclosure. Congress finds that the lack of Federal requirements for pay stubs and payroll record inspections hinders efforts to address wage violations. A survey showed many low-wage workers were underpaid or not paid overtime, with a majority not receiving pay stubs. Some employers use practices that make it hard for workers to calculate pay. Despite existing regulations, the lack of remedies limits the effectiveness of pay record keeping. The Supreme Court ruled in Anderson v. Mt. Clemens Pottery Co. that if an employer fails to keep required records under the Fair Labor Standards Act, the burden shifts to the employer to disprove the employee's evidence of work hours and compensation. Many courts have failed to shift this burden, giving equal weight to employer testimony and employee evidence. SEC. 3. PAY STUB REQUIREMENTS. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include a new disclosure requirement for employers to provide specific information to non-exempt employees within 15 days of hiring or any changes in pay or other details. This includes details on pay rates, employer names, and contact information. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include a new disclosure requirement for employers to provide specific information to non-exempt employees within 15 days of hiring or any changes in pay or other details. This includes details on pay rates, employer names, and contact information. Employers must also provide detailed information on each pay stub, including pay period, employee name, total hours worked, gross and net wages, and salary amount for the period. The new disclosure requirement under the amended Fair Labor Standards Act mandates employers to provide specific pay details to non-exempt employees within 15 days of hiring or any pay changes. This includes information on piece-rate units earned, applicable piece rate, total commission or other rates paid, overtime hours worked with hourly rates, additional compensation or benefits provided, and any deductions with explanations. The disclosure requirements under the amended Fair Labor Standards Act mandate employers to provide specific pay details to non-exempt employees within 15 days of hiring or any pay changes. This includes information on compensation, benefits, allowances, reimbursements, bonuses, paid leave, employer contributions to health care and retirement accounts, and additional forms of pay required by State or local law. The amended Fair Labor Standards Act requires employers to disclose specific pay details to non-exempt employees, including compensation, benefits, allowances, reimbursements, and bonuses. The pay stub must be provided each pay period and can be given as a separate document, a detachable part of a paycheck, or electronically. Recordkeeping requirements have also been updated. The amended Fair Labor Standards Act now requires employers to keep records of pay stub information for three years. Employers must also provide copies of employee records upon request and notify employees of their right to receive a pay stub within 15 days of hire. The Pay Stub Disclosure Act requires employers to provide employees with a pay stub containing specific information, including contact details for the Department of Labor. Employers must give this notice to existing employees within 15 days of the Act's effective date. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the section heading of the Fair Labor Standards Act. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. In General, the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is further amended to increase employer liability for violations of certain subsections. An employer who violates subsections (e) or (f) of section 11 will be liable to the affected employee for specified amounts. Additionally, failure to maintain required records or allow employee access to them will result in penalties. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to increase employer liability for violations. Employers who fail to keep sufficient records as required by section 11(c) will face penalties. Employees can provide credible evidence to create a rebuttable presumption of accurate records. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to define a pay stub as a paper itemizing wages and deductions. Regulations and technical assistance will be provided. SEC. 6. REGULATIONS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.

The Secretary of Labor must prescribe regulations within 1 year of this Act, including a list of similar state and local laws. Guidance on compliance and technical assistance will be provided to achieve the Act's objectives.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments in this Act will take effect 6 months after final regulations are issued by the Secretary of Labor, but no later than 18 months after the Act's enactment.
